message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a progressive motor neuron disease, and among the options, only Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis matches the symptoms. Guillain-Barré syndrome usually starts with numbness and tingling in the limbs, and Myasthenia gravis usually presents with fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity. Spinal muscular atrophy typically presents in infancy. The presence of pooling of oral secretions suggests bulbar involvement in ALS. The differential diagnosis also includes other motor neuron diseases such as primary lateral sclerosis, progressive muscular atrophy, and spinal muscular atrophy with lower extremity predominance, but the given symptoms match ALS the most.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms the patient presents with are consistent with Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Progressive weakness in arms and legs is a key feature of ALS, as well as difficulty swallowing and holding the head up. Deep tendon reflexes are reduced in the upper extremities and increased in the lower extremities, which is typical of ALS. Sensation to light touch, pinprick, and vibration are intact, making Guillain-Barré syndrome less likely. Myasthenia gravis is characterized by muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest, while spinal muscular atrophy typically presents earlier in life.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The progressive weakness in the arms and legs, difficulty swallowing, and holding the head up points towards Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). This is further supported by the decreased muscle strength and tone in the upper extremities and hyperactive deep tendon reflexes in the left lower extremity. Myasthenia gravis would present with fluctuating weakness, while Guillain-Barré syndrome and spinal muscular atrophy would present with more symmetric weakness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The progressive weakness in arms and legs, difficulty swallowing, and pooling of oral secretions all suggest Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The decreased muscle tone and strength in the upper extremities along with the difference in deep tendon reflexes also support this diagnosis. Guillain-Barré syndrome typically presents with ascending paralysis, myasthenia gravis primarily affects the skeletal muscles involved in breathing and swallowing, and spinal muscular atrophy typically presents earlier in life.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The progressive weakness in the arms and legs, along with difficulty swallowing and holding the head up, suggests a motor neuron disease. Among the options, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) fits the symptoms most accurately. The decreased muscle strength and tone, along with hyperreflexia in the left lower extremity, are consistent with ALS as well. Guillain-Barré syndrome and myasthenia gravis usually present with ascending paralysis, while spinal muscular atrophy is typically seen in infancy or childhood.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of weakness in arms and legs, difficulty swallowing, and decreased muscle strength and tone are consistent with the diagnosis of Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The deep tendon reflexes are asymmetric, which is common in ALS. Guillain-Barré syndrome typically presents with a rapidly progressive ascending paralysis, while Myasthenia gravis typically presents with muscle weakness that improves with rest. Spinal muscular atrophy typically presents in childhood.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The progressive weakness in limbs, difficulty swallowing, and holding head up suggests Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Guillain-Barré syndrome usually presents with symmetric ascending weakness, but this patient has asymmetry in deep tendon reflexes. Myasthenia gravis causes muscle weakness but it’s not accompanied by decreased muscle tone. Spinal muscular atrophy usually starts in childhood, and this patient is 62 years old.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of progressive weakness in arms and legs with difficulty swallowing and holding her head up suggest a motor neuron disease. ALS is the most likely diagnosis as it is characterized by progressive degeneration of the upper and lower motor neurons, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy. Guillain-Barré syndrome typically presents with ascending paralysis and sensory abnormalities. Myasthenia gravis presents with fluctuating weakness that improves with rest and worsens with exertion. Spinal muscular atrophy typically presents in childhood with progressive muscle weakness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest upper and lower motor neuron dysfunction, which fits with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The other options, Guillain-Barré and myasthenia gravis, present with different patterns of weakness and are unlikely to cause pooling of oral secretions. Spinal muscular atrophy usually presents in childhood.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a lower motor neuron involvement, which is seen in Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Guillain-Barré syndrome affects the peripheral nerves and would have shown more sensory symptoms. Myasthenia gravis primarily affects the muscles of the face and throat, and Spinal muscular atrophy affects the motor nerve cells in the spinal cord.
